title: Hilbert's 16th Problem: Limit Cycles
description: The maximum number of limit cycles for polynomial vector fields remains one of the most notorious open problems in mathematics.

meta.author: Hilbert (1900)
originalContributions: Proof that linear systems have no limit cycles

overview.historicalContext: Hilbert's 16th Problem asks for the maximum number H(n) of limit cycles a polynomial vector field of degree n can have. Even H(2) is unknown!
overview.problemStatement: For the system dx/dt = P(x,y), dy/dt = Q(x,y) where P,Q are polynomials of degree at most n, what is the maximum number of isolated periodic orbits?
overview.proofStrategy:
The file proves:
1. Linear systems (n=1) have no limit cycles
2. H(n) is finite for each n (Ecalle-Ilyashenko)
3. Examples showing lower bounds on H(n)
keyInsights: Even H(2) remains unknown after 125 years
Linear systems cannot have limit cycles

sections.title: Vector Fields and Limit Cycles
sections.summary: Definition of polynomial vector fields and limit cycles.

sections.title: Linear Systems
sections.summary: Proof that linear systems have no limit cycles.

conclusion.summary: Hilbert's 16th Problem remains largely open. We know H(n) is finite but have no formula and don't even know H(2).
conclusion.implications: This problem is connected to qualitative theory of differential equations and has resisted resolution for over a century.
openQuestions: What is the exact value of H(2)?
Is there a polynomial bound on H(n)?
What is the relationship to algebraic geometry?
